title: 110_hr244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. The disparity in investment between the US and its trading partners is leading to declining educational performance in the US compared to other countries in a global marketplace. The performance of students in the United States is compared to their counterparts in other countries. In a global marketplace, US businesses struggle to fund worker education and training that is provided at no cost by other countries. The current workforce environment creates competitive pressures for domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers abroad. It is crucial for the US government to reverse this trend to preserve national security, the middle class, and the welfare of workers while remaining globally competitive. Public-private partnerships in the United States, like the research and development tax credit, help advance the needs of citizens, businesses, and communities. Businesses are effective at training the workforce by tailoring programs to available jobs and utilizing new methods. The United States aims to improve cost effectiveness by encouraging businesses to train the workforce for high-paying technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers. This Act provides incentives for businesses and individuals to support the educational development of knowledge workers. The Act aims to encourage businesses and individuals to support educational development for knowledge workers in the United States by providing incentives for information and communications technology education and training investments. This will help businesses better utilize training dollars and maximize the skills of newly trained individuals. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATIONS TECHNOLOGY EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAM EXPENSES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section providing incentives for information and communications technology education and training expenses. The new section provides a tax credit for 50 percent of information and communications technology education and training program expenses incurred by the taxpayer for the benefit of employees or individuals. The credit is subject to limitations and coordination with the employer. The new section offers a tax credit for 50% of expenses related to an education and training program in information and communications technology. The credit is limited to $4,000 per individual, with a potential increase to $5,000 for specific programs and individuals in designated zones or communities. The new tax credit applies to education and training programs in specific designated zones or communities, including empowerment zones, enterprise communities, renewal communities, school districts with at least 50% of students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunches, and disaster areas designated by the Secretary of Agriculture. The tax credit applies to education and training programs in designated zones or communities, including disaster areas designated by the Secretary of Agriculture. The Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999 provides tax credits for education and training programs in designated zones or communities, including those in Rural Economic Area Partnership Zones, areas under Indian tribal government jurisdiction, or by employers with 200 or fewer employees. The term 'information technology education and training program expenses' refers to expenses incurred for participating in relevant programs, including coursework, certification testing, and programs authorized under specific legislation. The term 'information technology education and training program' includes expenses for coursework, certification testing, programs registered by the Department of Labor, and other essential expenses for skill assessment in information and communications technology disciplines provided by accredited institutions in the United States. The term 'information technology education and training program' covers coursework, certification testing, and skill assessment in IT disciplines provided by accredited institutions in the United States, including commercial IT training providers and employer-owned IT training organizations. The term 'employer-owned information technology training organization' refers to a private sector organization that provides IT training to employees using internal resources. No other deductions or credits are allowed for expenses used to determine this credit, and it may reduce hope and lifetime learning credits. The credit under this section is reduced by information technology education and training program expenses taken into account in determining other credits. Rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 apply. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax reduced by other allowable credits. The credit for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax reduced by other allowable credits. The maximum credit is the regular tax minus the sum of credits under subpart A and previous sections, over the tentative minimum tax. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 30D outlines expenses for an information and communications technology education and training program. The amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4 defines an eligible educational institution. The amendment defines an eligible educational institution as one described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 or a commercial information and communications technology training provider. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment expands the definition of an eligible educational institution to include technology training providers. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code, with the effective date for these changes being after December 31, 2006. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is established. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, composed of up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, meets annually to develop guidelines for computer certification and training. The Board elects a Chairperson from its members who must be a member of an information technology industry trade association. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, consisting of up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, selects a Chairperson from its members who must be part of an IT industry trade association. The Board is responsible for creating guidelines for computer science and related subjects in college courses, as well as a list of IT training and certifications eligible for tax credits. Members serve without compensation and are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, consists of up to seven members who serve without compensation. They are reimbursed for travel expenses while performing services for the Board. Section 14(b) of the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Board.
